_exec_summary.SummaryText: Teminal Warehouse located at 1779 Marvo Drive Akron Ohio is a warehouse complex operating 5 days a week 17 hours per day and closes weekends and major holidays. There are nine buildings located within the complex and leases a porition of one building to R.E. Carroll. Topography is rolling hills with primarily residential areas in all directions surrounding the facility. The nearest residences are adjacent to the west side of the facility located next to the ball field emergency assembly area. There is a stormwater retention pond on the northwest corner that drains west/northwest into a creek that contains a minimal amount of water at low flow during the summer months. A railroad track runs along the east side of the facility outside of the fence line. Building 1 is 56,440 square feet L shaped hwere R.E. Carroll repackages and stores oil product prior to shipment. The remainder of the building is used by Terminal Whse for staging load and storage of non-oil products.There are no drains located within the building and only two bay doors leading to the ousdie near the repakaging areas. Building 2 is 62,886 square feet with a large portion used for administrative offices and the remainder used for the storage of non-hazardous materials prior to shipment. Building 3 is 9,648 square feet and is used for storage of hazardous materials prior to shipment. Building 4 is also 9,648 square feet in size and is used for stoage of hazardous materials and occationally used for the refregerated storage of between 40 and 100 drums of Multranol. There are no drains and the flooring slopes towards the center to cantain any potenial released materials.  A spill kit is located inear the loading dock door. Buildings 5 & 6  are 19,296 square feet combined and are divided by a cement block wall with a bay door for passage between. Hazardous materials are stored in these buildings prior to shipment. As with building 4 there are no floor drains and the flooring slopes towards the center to ca

ntain any possible releases. Building 8 is 122, 097 square feet and is used for the storage of a wide variety of non-hazardous solid and liquid materials prior to shipment it contains no floor drains, slopes towards the center and has a spill kit located near the loading dock doors. Builidng 9 is 121,866 square feet, used for the storage of a wide variety of non-hazardous solid and liquid materials prior to shipment, contains no floor drains and slopes toward the center and also contains a two spill kits located at the loading docks. 
 Building 7 is 38, 952 square feet divided into four sections and is the building where extremely hazardous chemicals and flammable materials are/will be stored. The building has a sprinkler system , smoke alarms, seven (7) fire pull alarms and seven (7) power horn alams to alert employees when to evacuate the building. All powered industrial trucks used in this area are designated ES constructed and assembled for use in atmospheres containing flammable vapors or dusts. Although not currently stored in amounts equal to or exceeding the Reportable Quantities of materials contained in this RMP, future business predications indicate quantities could be reached or exceeded from time to time beginning in the fall of 2008 for Dimethylamine CAS # 124-40-3  at 46% mixture - and a blend of Toluene 2,4 Diisocyanate CAS # 584-84-9 at 80% and Toluene 2,4 Diisocyante at 20%. Epichlorohydrin CAS #106-89-8 at 99% will be stored at approximately 100,000 pounds daily beginning in April 2008.
Terminal Warehouse takes every precaution necessary to prevent the release of chemicals whether it is hazardous or non-hazardous through continuous training that includes proper handling techniques, proper personnel protective equipment requirements and steps to take should a release occur. Its primary focus is on the safety and health of its employees, responders, the general public and the protection of the environment. Employees are not expected or trained to co

mbat extremely hazardous chemical releases except in cases where incidental or minor releases can be absorbed, neutralized or otherwise controlled at the time of the release by uprighting a drum or plugging a small hole in a tote or drum, provided it does not pose and immediate safety or health hazard. If the release cannot be contolled as described above, all employees in the immediate vicinity of the release are to evacuate the area and notify Sandy Rilling Compliance Manager and provide information on the material released, amount released and location of release. The Compliance Manager will evaluate the situation and notify the Springfield Fire Department, Summit County Hazmat, Sunpro and Ohio EPA Emergency Services as appropriate; notify team leaders and supervisors to evacuate the area or overall facility if necessary insuring all employees are accounted for; oversee the erection of barricades to establish an isolation zone and communicate with responders any information releated to the release including the nature, location, and material released. To avoid confusion and to prevent anxiety within the general public, Ron Goson, Owner and Bill Hanlon, President of Terminal Warehouse is the designated spokespersons. Should the release reqire the need to evacuate the surrounding area they will be responsible for informing the public of the need to evacuate, what is being done to correct the sitiuation and when the situation has been corrected.
